awd_titl_txt: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Lake Baikal Responses to Global Change: The Role of Genetic, Functional and Taxonomic Diversity in the Plankton
awd_abstract_narration:
Human-induced global change is altering most ecosystems on Earth. Highly diverse ecosystems may be better buffered against change, maintaining key functions even as the physical environment changes. How ecosystems respond will likely depend on their biodiversity, but how different components of biological diversity (biodiversity) determine ecosystem responses to global change are still poorly understood. Genetic diversity enhances the ability of populations to adapt to change and functional diversity allows different species to carry out key ecosystem functions, but little is known about how these components of diversity will interact with each other and with the number of species present in a changing environment. Sixty years of existing ecological data, field sampling, genetic analyses, experiments, and  mathematical models will be used by an interdisciplinary team of researchers to examine multiple aspects of biodiversity in the largest, oldest and most biologically diverse lake in the world, Lake Baikal in Siberia. A major goal of the project will be to develop the ability to predict how this ecosystem will respond to rising temperatures and other stressors. Holding 20% of world's unfrozen fresh water, this UNESCO World Heritage Site is recognized internationally as a globally important freshwater resource, a treasure trove of biodiversity and a unique natural laboratory in which to study evolution. With an unprecedented diversity of endemic species found nowhere else, Lake Baikal serves as a model for ecosystems with highly unique biota and cold aquatic environments undergoing rapid warming.

Researchers and students will engage in an interdisciplinary international collaborative research program. Funding will support graduate training in both applied and basic areas of science, including molecular biology, ecology, and informatics. Data collected by this project will be publically available so that they can be used by other scientists and educators. Project results will be communicated to environmental organizations in Russia and the US and to a US-based film team planning an IMAX movie about Baikal and freshwater conservation. School teachers from Michigan, Texas and Tennessee will participate in the project and, together with researchers, develop educational activities on aquatic ecology, biological diversity and global change.

por.por_cntn:
Anthropogenic global change is profoundly altering most ecosystems on Earth.  Understanding how ecological communities will change in the future is one of the main challenges facing ecologists today. Freshwater lakes in cold regions may be especially sensitive to rising temperatures. High genetic and functional diversity within individual species and in ecological communities, as well as the taxonomic diversity (presence of many different species), may help offset the negative effects of risng temperatures and other ecosystem stressors  because there will likely be organisms adequately adapted to novel conditions. In this project we investigated how diverse the key players of the Lake Baikal plankton food web are and how they may respond to changing environment. Lake Baikal is the oldest, largest by volume and the most diverse lake in the world, it is often considered the natural laboratory for evolution and could be a model system for understanding how lakes in cold regions may respond to warming. Lake Baikal, including its open waters, has a high number of endemic species, organisms that occur only in that lake and nowhere else. These endemic plankton (microscopic algae, phytoplankton and their microscopic grazers, zooplankton) may be especially vulnerable to rising temperatures because they are adapted to cold, stable environments of the lake. 

We used a variety of apploaches, from sampling diverse locations across the whole lake to characterize the diversity of the microbial plankton and patterns of nutrient limitation, to laboratory experiments with both endemic and cosmopolitan (occurring in a lot of ecosystems) species to compare their performance, to mathematical models predicting planktonic food web composition and dynamics in the future.  

We found that endemic diatoms (one of the dominant types of phytoplankton in the lake) thrive at low temperatures but cannot grow at temperatures above 14 degrees Celsius. These diatoms also show low genetic diversity, which may put them at an even greater disadvantage in the changing conditions. In contrast, cosmopolitan phytoplankton were able to grow at a wide range of temperatures, making them more resilient to warming. Using a mathematical model of the planktonic food web in Lake Baikal, we found that the declining duration of ice cover significantly decreases the ability of endemic diatoms to reach high densities, as commonly happens in the spring. This decline in endemic diatoms may dramatically change the whole food web and the functioning of Lake Baikal ecosystem. We also for the first time characterized extensively the bacterial communities in different parts of the lake and found that Lake Baikal harbors diverse and often unknown types of bacteria. The major drivers of bacterial community structure are temperature and nutrients. We also showed that bacterioplankton functional redundancy, where many species perform similar funcitons, is low at low temperatures. The results of our project show that the planktonic food web of Lake Baikal may be vulnerable to anthropogenic stressors, warming in particular, and that in the future we may see a shift from the dominance by endemic species to more cosmopolitan species.

Two graduate students and a postdoctoral researcher were trained on the project. They learned diverse field and laboratory techniques, data analyses and the research article writing. The researchers on the project presented their results and the broad problem of global change effects on aquatic ecosystems in numerous talks to a wide range of audiences, from other scientists, to K-12 teachers, to general public.
